body:
I have to write a blog post of how to do it ;-) sorry for the delay, I will do it this week.

To make it short, in the directory where the slides lives:
1. Add this `custom.css` file: https://gist.github.com/damianavila/6211198
2. Run this little snippet: https://gist.github.com/damianavila/6211211
3. Run `python -m SimpleHTTPServer 8001`
4. Open Mozilla Firefox browser and point to localhost:8001
5. Add ?print.pdf to the end of the url (ie, `http://127.0.0.1:8001/jevans.slides.html?print-pdf`)
6. Print to pdf, use Landscape orientation

And you will get this one (check jevans.pdf from this repo: https://github.com/damianavila/Miscellaneus).

Hope it helps.

Damián.

Thanks so much for the instructions, Damián! I'll try this out soon.

> 3. Run python -m SimpleHTTPServer 8001

thanks for the instructions, @damianavila : are these tricks that http://slideviewer.herokuapp.com/ already using? would be good to get this into nbconvert

@damianavila, could we apply both of these fixes ourselves in nbconvert?  It would be nice not to have to apply them manually on every slideshow.

Also, I noticed two problems on slideviewer:
1. Long slides can't be scrolled vertically, which means they can't be read at all.
2. Mathjax won't render.

[Here](http://slideviewer.herokuapp.com/urls/raw.github.com/profjsb/python-seminar/master/DataFiles_and_Notebooks/00_AdvancedPythonConcepts/advanced_notebook.ipynb#/11) is an illustration of both problems, using a notebook from @profjsb.

> thanks for the instructions, @damianavila : are these tricks that http://slideviewer.herokuapp.com/ already using? would be good to get this into nbconvert

@ivanov slideviewer has the first implementation of reveal... it is using an old css styling, because of that, there is no problem... but it is buggy. I have to update it to the last IPython.nbconvert... and deal with this css problem...

> @damianavila, could we apply both of these fixes ourselves in nbconvert? It would be nice not to have to apply them manually on every slideshow.

@fperez this was my first idea... but at the time we rewrite reveal it was not possible because of some problems with less and boopstrap... the description of the problem is here: https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/3012
But as far as I know we have not migrated to v3 yet... so it is difficult to fix it, maybe we can think in a workaround (like a post-processor or something else). Thoughts?

> Also, I noticed two problems on slideviewer:
> 
> Long slides can't be scrolled vertically, which means they can't be read at all.
> 
> Mathjax won't render.
> 
> Here is an illustration of both problems, using a notebook from @profjsb.

Yes, slideviewer is using the old nbconvert... I have to update it as soon as possible... ;-)
Is possible a `--to pdfslides` for making this in automate way?
Working on this in a few hours ;-)
That's great Damian!! :D
Is this fixed @damianavila ?
There is no easy way to fix it until we upgrade to boopstrap3... so I would like to keep it open until we can get an solution...
OK, thanks, targeting to 3.0 then.

I've tested the reveal-suggested stylesheet approach recently (adding `?print-pdf` to the URL and printing in chrome), and it now seems to work like a charm.

Should we just close this one?

> I've tested the reveal-suggested stylesheet approach recently (adding ?print-pdf to the URL and printing in chrome), and it now seems to work like a charm.

Without making any more? Do you have highligthed code? I tested a few minutes ago and still no working because we have, inside the `style.min.css`, an `!important` in the fontcolor at the `@media print`...

No, I didn't check highlighting. Just that I would get a half-decent PDF that was broadly correct.

Honestly, given the notebook allows for presentations that are so dynamic (live JS, code, interactive controls, etc), nobody can really expect the generated pdfs to match the live presentation, nor should we promise so.

I think it's fine to leave this open to track what we can improve on this front, but only if there are concrete things we can really fix. But leaving a vague 'make pdf better' issue open isn't really useful, and we should just delegate to whatever reveal can do on that front, accepting it will be limited.

> Honestly, given the notebook allows for presentations that are so dynamic (live JS, code, interactive controls, etc), nobody can really expect the generated pdfs to match the live presentation, nor should we promise so.

I agree... 

> but only if there are concrete things we can really fix.

And there is a concrete thing to fix... just we need to wait until the upgrade to boopstrap3 to make it real... and I think that having highlighted code worth to wait for this fix (and an open issue until is fixed).

Maybe the right move is to close this one, because the title is not actually representing the current issue, but open a new issue with a detailed explanation about the missing highlighted code, targeting to 3.0.

Thoughts?

On Mon, Feb 3, 2014 at 7:37 AM, Damián Avila notifications@github.comwrote:

> Maybe the right move is to close this one, because the title is not
> actually representing the current issue, but open a new issue with a
> detailed explanation about the missing highlighted code, targeting to 3.0.
> 
> Thoughts?

+1 on that.

> +1 on that.

I need someone to close this one for me. Thanks.

Very nice. This is such a powerful feature, printing reveal slides to pdf.

On that note, is there an open issue tracking what's remaining, such as:

>  a new issue with a detailed explanation about the missing highlighted code, targeting to 3.0.

and whatever other fixes are needed see this fully implemented? I looked around, but didn't find one. 

As I understand it, we are able to get pdf's via the slides (I also was able to do so with the suggestion from @fperez, using `?print-pdf` at the end of the url), but no code highlighting. To resolve the highlighting issue in the meantime, is the recommended workaround still this: http://www.damian.oquanta.info/posts/a-little-hack-to-get-a-pdf-from-your-ipython-slides.html ?

Thanks :)

To fix the highlighting issue, we need to migrate to bootstrap 3... and the migration is "going on" right now (WIP PR)... so we can probably fix this issue sooner... in the meantime, the recommended workaround is the linked one by yourself before...
@damianavila, thanks for the reply. I did attempt to do it, however, still had problems with some of the images being segmented across multiple pages. I'll look into it more when I have time. :)
OK, if you need more help, let me know ;-)

i see this is closed, but i'm having quite a few issues even after following the instructions:
1. on chrome it doesn't work at all (all pages after the first page are blank)
2. on firefox/safari images appear distorted (i.e. take up more space than during the slideshow).

here is the slideshow in case someone has ideas. 

http://slideviewer.herokuapp.com/github/satra/rscourse/blob/master/brainconnect-tutorial.ipynb?theme=sky#/

(also: is the live slideshow mode gone?)

The print-pdf option usually break in reveal.js itself, so probably the problem is there... I will investigate with your slides to see where the problem could be...

Regarding the Live Reveal Slideshow, it lives as an independent extension here: https://github.com/damianavila/live_reveal

I hope we can make it enough good to be the canonical live slides for the Jupyter/IPython presentation mode. Let see how far we can go :stuck_out_tongue_winking_eye:
@damianavila -  the live reveal slideshow is very cool. thanks.

@damianavila - were you able to look at the printing issue by any chance? i need to create some handouts for a class tomorrow and while i'm happy to point people to the online resource, having something on hand would be useful for the students.
I will try to look on this on the evening... I can not assure you a successful solution for tomorrow because usually it is a mess to fix it, but I will do my best! Is the same slide you linked above?
thanks @damianavila - it's at the same place. i'll try to see if i can do anything with reveal as well.

Hey all, just wanted to pipe in here and say, this is an integral component of my development and scientific workflow now, and it's so close to being complete. There are still the kinks (e.g., consistent printing to pdf), that make the IPython + Reveal.js promise always anxiety-inducing. I've encountered this a few times, and have had to scramble to see it deliver. 

Once it and Live Reveal mature, this will be a godsend to many who use ipython. Thank you all for the hard work and I am really looking forward to contributing more. :smile:

@satra can you share the generated pdf from your slides? I want to know if the quality if worth the effort I am undertaking now :)

yes I am facing the problem of exporting my slides to pdf because the teaching materials "have to" be in pdf (not my rules) and not just accessible on the web...
